Legal_Issue: Judicial review of a PRRA decision after removal
Application_Facts: Applicant is a Tamil from Sri Lanka who alleged risk of persecution; PRRA was denied and applicant was removed from Canada despite seeking judicial review
Decision_Outcome: Application dismissed, no general questions certified
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of negative PRRA decision
Court_Ruling: Application is largely moot post-removal, but discretion allows hearing due to legal uncertainty and adversarial context
Defendant_Behavior: Enforced removal following denial of PRRA
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged risk of persecution in Sri Lanka
Legal_Standard: Mootness doctrine in judicial review proceedings
Assessment_Factor: Risk of persecution upon return to country of origin
Procedural_Issue: Filing of judicial review after removal from Canada
Review_Standard: Reasonableness or correctness, depending on issue
Evidence_Used: PRRA application materials, allegations of persecution
Legal_Provision_Cited: Sections of IRPA relating to PRRA and removal
Evidence_Assessed: Allegations of persecution based on ethnicity and country conditions
Relief_Sought: Reassessment of PRRA or return to Canada
Governing_Rule: PRRA assesses risk prior to removal; court may lack authority to order return post-removal
Harm_Assessment: Risk of persecution if returned to Sri Lanka
Cause_Description: Applicant challenged negative PRRA decision after being removed from Canada
Evidence_Handling: Considered in context of mootness and legal uncertainty
Legal_Provision: IRPA provisions on PRRA and removal
Jurisdictional_Issue: Court's authority to hear case after removal
Evidence_Assessment: Limited due to mootness, but considered for discretionary hearing
Decision_Rationale: Post-removal judicial review is largely moot, but court exercised discretion to hear case due to legal significance and adversarial process
Legal_Standard_Applied: Mootness exception in public law contexts
